Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps EAGER: UC Biomedical Research Acceleration, Integration, and Development (UC BRAID/CAI) I-Corps Hub Proposal
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal seeks support for a UC Biomedical Research Acceleration, Integration, and Development (UC BRAID/CAI) I-Corps Hub consortium, a coordinated effort among the UC medical campuses with the goal of facilitating translation and accelerating promising technologies at the UCs. The campuses include: Davis, Irvine, Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco. The program will implement a training and education curriculum in order to train entrepreneurs on the UC BRAID campuses by leveraging the infrastructure of the UC Center for Accelerated Innovation (UC CAI) housed at UCLA, along with the NSF-approved LLP curriculum - through accessing the experience and knowledge that helped draft the initial Lean Launch Pad for Life Science/Healthcare (that was hosted by UCSF). The course will provide real world, hands-on education and training on what it is needed to start a scalable company.

The I-Corps Hub will leverage UC CAI's training and education emphasis and be able to provide: 1) world-class scientific and clinical research that generates a flow of technologies which are potentially on the brink of commercialization; 2) leadership in NSF I-Corps education for life science/healthcare that will help deliver a strong offering to its component campuses; 3) utilization of the infrastructure built by the UC CAI to deliver education and training components across the UC campuses (as well as across departments and schools) to attract entrepreneurs at all levels; and 4) robust and proven curriculum that encourages entrepreneurship, networking, interdisciplinary team building and world-class teaching and mentorship to all levels of interested entrepreneurs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UC Biomedical Research Acceleration, Integration and Development (UC BRAID) / Center for Accelerated Innovation (CAI) I-Corps Hub provided innovators with hands-on training in the process of commercializing therapeutics, devices and diagnostics. A training and education curriculum was implemented by leveraging the infrastructure of the UC CAI and the NSF-approved curriculum developed by UC San Francisco, Lean LaunchPad. Lean LaunchPad for Life Science/Healthcare teaches researchers and clinicians how to move their technology from an academic lab or clinic into the commercial world.  Teams learn how to assess regulatory risk before they design and build a product, gather data essential to customer purchases before developing the science or technology, define clinical utility before spending millions of dollars and identify financing vehicles before they are required.

More specifically, the UC BRAID/CAI Lean LaunchPad course taught participants a mindset and process to extend their focus beyond the laboratory/clinic to the market and evaluate whether the idea or technology they have has a viable commercialization path. This knowledge gained by scientists and clinicians on assessing the viability of entrepreneurial ventures increases the potential commercial success of very early stage ventures in the life science/healthcare domain, thereby accelerating the translation of technology from the lab or clinic to the marketplace. Feedback from the participants indicated they have learned a life skill that will continue to benefit them whether in an entrepreneurial venture or other pursuit.

The following are a few examples of outcomes four-months post-course completion. Anecdotally, two teams have been accepted into accelerators.  iSonoHealth, a collaborative team between industry, Stanford and UCSF roots, has just been accepted into one of the country’s most competitive accelerators, Y Combinator.  Enable Biosciences, a team from UC Berkeley, is at StartX/QB3, an alliance between Stanford’s accelerator and biotech labs managed by QB3.  Admission into these accelerators is a major achievement given the intensity of competition for these slots. Several teams have applied for SBIR grants that are currently under review, and a select number of promising teams that are ready to fundraise continue to be actively mentored.

Translation from academe by identifying promising biomedical product opportunities to the commercial world can produce substantial benefit for the economy and society.  By providing researchers with tools they need to successfully move products to commercialization, the gap between technology and the marketplace for products that provide health benefits to society will be decreased.

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2015
Modified by: Michael Palazzolo
